title: The Funeral
description: An image of the original hand-written lyrics was posted by Band of Horses to their Instagram account March 22, 2016, with caption:

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: I'm coming up only to hold you under
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: While often read as a reflection on the neverending process of grieving, Ben Bridwell has said in an interview that the song is about his dread of fake, empty social occasions – this line then could either stress his frustration at the omniprevalence of such occasions, or reinforcing that he would rather attend a billion-day funeral than have to participate. The original handwritten lyric sheets reads ‘Every occasion through one billion ways funeral’, with an underlying pencil ‘days’ having been

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: And coming up only to show you're wrong
And to know you is hard, we wonder
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: This is an interesting lyric in which a simple addition of a punctuation mark could change the whole meaning of the lyric, and even of the whole song. Here, the lyric implies that Ben is not “golden”, not a good person, and everything is wrong.

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: To know you all wrong, we were
Ooh, ooh
Ooh, ooh
Really too late to call, so we wait for
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: I love this double entendre, because the phrase “morning to wake you” can also be interpreted as “mourning to wake you” and I personally go with that. Reason being the song is literally called “the funeral”.

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: Morning to wake you is all we got
But to know me as hardly golden
Is to know me all wrong, they were
At every occasion, I'll be ready for the funeral
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: As referenced in a previous annotation, this song is really open to interpretation. We can compare the tree to someone who is providing help, and if the addict doesn’t hang onto this person they may meet their fate.

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: At every occasion once more, it's called the funeral
At every occasion, oh, I'm ready for the funeral
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: The bleak, almost biblical imagery of the dead leaves – with a suggestion of suicide – mirrors the singer’s despair at the hollowness of the occasion.

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: At every occasion of one billion day funeral
I'm coming up only to you show you down for
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: While this song is more or less open to interpretation, the perspective I took when struggling with my own affairs stuck with me. Think of this verse coming from the perspective of yourself or your family. The times you realize and face you are addicted are short and upsetting–you keep feeding yourself lies which eventually succumb to the truth (at times). Eventually, (Verse 2 top two) your caring family/friends/else have no expectation and effort to assist you as you may be far beyond anyone’s

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: And coming up only to you show you're wrong
To the outside, the dead leaves lay on the lawn
'Fore they died, and had trees to hang there upon
Ooh, ooh
Ooh, ooh
At every occasion, I'll be ready for the funeral
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: I listened to this one driving up to my grandmother’s funeral. It cries out the way that death strips us to the bone if we fully let it.

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: At every occasion once more, it's called the funeral
At every occasion, oh, I'm ready for the funeral
At every occasion of one billion day funeral
